title: 106_s1509
content: The Act may be cited as the "Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act Amendments of 2000". The Congress finds that Indian tribes and Alaska Native organizations participating in programs under the Indian Employment, Training, and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 have improved employment services, helped more people secure jobs, transitioned tribal members from welfare to work, and shown the value of integrating employment, training, education, and related services. The Indian Employment, Training, and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 should be strengthened by including all Federal programs that emphasize the value of work in a demonstration program of an Indian or Alaska Native organization. This initiative should have the support of officials with policymaking authority from the Department of the Interior and other relevant Federal agencies. The Indian Employment, Training, and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 aims to integrate employment, training, and services to reduce joblessness, promote economic development on Indian lands, and align with self-determination and self-governance policies. The Indian Employment, Training, and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 aims to integrate employment, training, and services to reduce joblessness and promote economic development on Indian lands, aligning with self-determination and self-governance policies. Amendments are proposed to this Act. Amendments to the Indian Employment, Training, and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 include redefining "federal agency" and focusing on assisting Indian youth and adults in the workforce for self-sufficiency and job success. The amendments to the Indian Employment, Training, and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 aim to redefine "federal agency" and support Indian youth and adults in the workforce for self-sufficiency and job opportunities. Amendments to the Indian Employment, Training, and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 include provisions for waiver requests and job creation opportunities. The Indian Employment, Training, and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 allows tribal governments to use a percentage of funds for creating employment opportunities, with the percentage determined by the rate of unemployment in the tribe's service area or a minimum of 10 percent. The funds used must come from a Federal agency under a specific formula. SEC. 4. REPORT ON EXPANDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR PROGRAM INTEGRATION. The Secretary, Secretary of Health and Human Services, Secretary of Labor, and tribes involved in the integration initiative must submit a report to Congress within a year on expanding human resource and economic development programs. The report will explore the feasibility of Joint Funding Agreements for tribes to access coordinated funds from various agencies and recommend ways to remove barriers to program integration. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect upon enactment.
